- The ID of your Respoke app. This must be passed either to
respoke.connect, respoke.createClient, or to client.connect.

endpoint. This is only used when `developmentMode` is set to `true`.

tags.name: [params.developmentMode=false]

- Indication to obtain an authentication token from the service.
Note: Your app must be in developer mode to use this feature. This is not intended as a long-term mode of
operation and will limit the services you will be able to use.

tags.name: [params.onDirectConnection]
tags.description:
- Callback for when this client's user
receives a request for a direct connection.

description.full:
respoke.Client is the top-level interface to the API. Interacting with Respoke should be done using a respoke.Client instance.

There are two ways to get a client:

 var client = respoke.createClient(clientParams);
 // . . . set stuff up, then . . .
 client.connect(connectParams);

or

 // creates client and connects to Respoke all at once
 var client = respoke.connect(allParams);

A client does the following things:

  1. authentication with the Respoke API
  2. receives server-side app-specific information
  3. tracks connections and presence
  4. provides methods to get and interact with tracked entities (like groups and endpoints)
  5. stores default settings for calls and direct connections
  6. automatically reconnects to the API when network activity is lost*

*If developmentMode is set to true. If not using developmentMode, disable automatic reconnect by sending reconnect: false and listening to the Client's disconnect event to fetch a new brokered auth token, then call client.connect() with the new token.
description.summary: respoke.Client is the top-level interface to the API. Interacting with Respoke should be done using a respoke.Client instance.
description.body:
There are two ways to get a client:

 var client = respoke.createClient(clientParams);
 // . . . set stuff up, then . . .
 client.connect(connectParams);

or

 // creates client and connects to Respoke all at once
 var client = respoke.connect(allParams);

A client does the following things:

  1. authentication with the Respoke API
  2. receives server-side app-specific information
  3. tracks connections and presence
  4. provides methods to get and interact with tracked entities (like groups and endpoints)
  5. stores default settings for calls and direct connections
  6. automatically reconnects to the API when network activity is lost*

*If developmentMode is set to true. If not using developmentMode, disable automatic reconnect by sending reconnect: false and listening to the Client's disconnect event to fetch a new brokered auth token, then call client.connect() with the new token.

description.full:
Connect to the Respoke infrastructure and authenticate using params.token.

After connect, the app auth session token is stored so it can be used in API requests.

This method attaches quite a few event listeners for things like group joining and connection status changes.

Usage

 client.connect({
     appId: "XXXXXXXX-XXXX-XXXX-XXXX-XXXXXXXXXXXXX",
     token: "XXXXXXXX-XXXX-XXXX-XXXX-XXXXXXXXXXXXX", // if not developmentMode
     developmentMode: false || true,
     // if developmentMode, otherwise your server will set endpointId
     endpointId: "billy"
 });
 client.listen("connect", function () { } );

If no params.token is given and developmentMode is set to true, it will attempt to obtain a token automatically. You must set an endpointId.

App auth session token expiration

If params.reconnect is set to true (which it is by default for developmentMode), the client will attempt to keep reconnecting each time the app auth session expires.

If not using developmentMode, automatic reconnect will be disabled. You will need to listen to the Client's disconnect event to fetch a new brokered auth token and call client.connect() with the new token.

 client.listen('disconnect', function () {

     // example method you implemented to get a new token from your server
     myServer.getNewRespokeAccessToken(function (newToken) {
         // reconnect with respoke.Client
         client.connect({ token: newToken });
     });

 });
description.summary: Connect to the Respoke infrastructure and authenticate using params.token.
description.body:
After connect, the app auth session token is stored so it can be used in API requests.

This method attaches quite a few event listeners for things like group joining and connection status changes.

Usage

 client.connect({
     appId: "XXXXXXXX-XXXX-XXXX-XXXX-XXXXXXXXXXXXX",
     token: "XXXXXXXX-XXXX-XXXX-XXXX-XXXXXXXXXXXXX", // if not developmentMode
     developmentMode: false || true,
     // if developmentMode, otherwise your server will set endpointId
     endpointId: "billy"
 });
 client.listen("connect", function () { } );

If no params.token is given and developmentMode is set to true, it will attempt to obtain a token automatically. You must set an endpointId.

App auth session token expiration

If params.reconnect is set to true (which it is by default for developmentMode), the client will attempt to keep reconnecting each time the app auth session expires.

If not using developmentMode, automatic reconnect will be disabled. You will need to listen to the Client's disconnect event to fetch a new brokered auth token and call client.connect() with the new token.

 client.listen('disconnect', function () {

     // example method you implemented to get a new token from your server
     myServer.getNewRespokeAccessToken(function (newToken) {
         // reconnect with respoke.Client
         client.connect({ token: newToken });
     });

 });

description.full:
This function contains the meat of the connection, the portions which can be repeated again on reconnect.

When reconnect is true, this function will be added in an event listener to the Client#disconnect event.

Using callbacks by passing params.onSuccess or params.onError will disable promises.
description.summary: This function contains the meat of the connection, the portions which can be repeated again on reconnect.
description.body:
When reconnect is true, this function will be added in an event listener to the Client#disconnect event.

Using callbacks by passing params.onSuccess or params.onError will disable promises.

description.full: These rely on the EventEmitter checking for duplicate event listeners in order for these not to be duplicated on reconnect.
description.summary: These rely on the EventEmitter checking for duplicate event listeners in order for these not to be duplicated on reconnect.

tags.name: name
tags.description: - The event name.

description.full: This event provides notification for when an incoming call is being received. If the user wishes to allow the call, evt.call.answer().
description.summary: This event provides notification for when an incoming call is being received. If the user wishes to allow the call, evt.call.answer().

code: that.listen('call', clientSettings.onCall);

tags.name: name
tags.description: - the event name.

description.full: This event is fired when the local end of the directConnection is available. It still will not be ready to send and receive messages until the 'open' event fires.
description.summary: This event is fired when the local end of the directConnection is available. It still will not be ready to send and receive messages until the 'open' event fires.

code:
that.listen('direct-connection', clientSettings.onDirectConnection);
            that.listen('join', clientSettings.onJoin);

description.full:
Set the presence for this client.

The value of presence can be a string, number, object, or array - in any format - depending on the needs of your application. The only requirement is that JSON.stringify() must work (no circular references).

 var myPresence = 'At lunch'
                 || 4
                 || { status: 'Away', message: 'At lunch' }
                 || ['Away', 'At lunch'];

 client.setPresence({
     presence: myPresence,
     onSuccess: function (evt) {
         // successfully updated my presence
     }
 });

Using callbacks by passing params.onSuccess or params.onError will disable promises.
description.summary: Set the presence for this client.
description.body:
The value of presence can be a string, number, object, or array - in any format - depending on the needs of your application. The only requirement is that JSON.stringify() must work (no circular references).

 var myPresence = 'At lunch'
                 || 4
                 || { status: 'Away', message: 'At lunch' }
                 || ['Away', 'At lunch'];

 client.setPresence({
     presence: myPresence,
     onSuccess: function (evt) {
         // successfully updated my presence
     }
 });

Using callbacks by passing params.onSuccess or params.onError will disable promises.

tags.name: [params.id]
tags.description: - Call ID.

tags.name: [params.endpointId]
tags.description:
- Endpoint ID. Warning: If you pass only the endpointId, this method
will just return the first call that matches. If you are placing multiple calls to the same endpoint,
pass in the call ID, too.

tags.name: params.create
tags.description: - whether or not to create a new call if the specified endpointId isn't found

description.full:
Get the Call with the endpoint specified.

// hang up on chad
var call = client.getCall({
    endpointId: 'chad'
});

if (call) {
    call.hangup()
}
description.summary: Get the Call with the endpoint specified.
description.body:
// hang up on chad
var call = client.getCall({
    endpointId: 'chad'
});

if (call) {
    call.hangup()
}

description.full:
Send a message to an endpoint.

client.sendMessage({
    endpointId: 'dan',
    message: "Jolly good."
});

Using callbacks by passing params.onSuccess or params.onError will disable promises.
description.summary: Send a message to an endpoint.
description.body:
client.sendMessage({
    endpointId: 'dan',
    message: "Jolly good."
});

Using callbacks by passing params.onSuccess or params.onError will disable promises.

tags.name: params.endpointId
tags.description: - The id of the endpoint that should be called.

tags.name: [params.onLocalMedia]
tags.description:
- Callback for receiving an HTML5 Video element
with the local audio and/or video attached.

tags.name: [params.onError]
tags.description:
- Callback for errors that happen during call setup or
media renegotiation.

tags.name: [params.onConnect]
tags.description:
- Callback for receiving an HTML5 Video element
with the remote audio and/or video attached.

tags.name: [params.onAllow]
tags.description:
- When setting up a call, receive notification that the
browser has granted access to media.

tags.name: [params.onHangup]
tags.description:
- Callback for being notified when the call has been hung
up.

tags.name: [params.onMute]
tags.description:
- Callback for changing the mute state on any type of media.
This callback will be called when media is muted or unmuted.

tags.name: [params.onAnswer]
tags.description: - Callback for when the callee answers the call.

tags.name: [params.onApprove]
tags.description:
- Callback for when the user approves local media. This
callback will be called whether or not the approval was based on user feedback. I. e., it will be called even if
the approval was automatic.

tags.name: [params.onRequestingMedia]
tags.description:
- Callback for when the app is waiting
for the user to give permission to start getting audio or video.

tags.name: [params.onStats]
tags.description:
- Callback for receiving statistical
information.

tags.name: [params.receiveOnly]
tags.description: - whether or not we accept media

tags.name: [params.sendOnly]
tags.description: - whether or not we send media

tags.name: [params.needDirectConnection]
tags.description: - flag to enable skipping media & opening direct connection.

tags.name: [params.forceTurn]
tags.description:
- If true, media is not allowed to flow peer-to-peer and must flow through
relay servers. If it cannot flow through relay servers, the call will fail.

tags.name: [params.disableTurn]
tags.description:
- If true, media is not allowed to flow through relay servers; it is
required to flow peer-to-peer. If it cannot, the call will fail.

tags.name: [params.previewLocalMedia]
tags.description:
- A function to call if the developer
wants to perform an action between local media becoming available and calling approve().

tags.name: [params.connectionId]
tags.description:
- The connection ID of the remoteEndpoint, if it is not desired to call
all connections belonging to this endpoint.

tags.name: [params.videoLocalElement]
tags.description: - Pass in an optional html video element to have local video attached to it.

tags.name: [params.videoRemoteElement]
tags.description: - Pass in an optional html video element to have remote video attached to it.

description.full:
Place an audio and/or video call to an endpoint.

// defaults to video when no constraints are supplied
client.startCall({
    endpointId: 'erin',
    onConnect: function (evt) { },
    onLocalMedia: function (evt) { }
});
description.summary: Place an audio and/or video call to an endpoint.
description.body:
// defaults to video when no constraints are supplied
client.startCall({
    endpointId: 'erin',
    onConnect: function (evt) { },
    onLocalMedia: function (evt) { }
});

the approval was automatic.

tags.name: [params.receiveOnly]
tags.description: - whether or not we accept media

tags.name: [params.sendOnly]
tags.description: - whether or not we send media

tags.name: [params.needDirectConnection]
tags.description: - flag to enable skipping media & opening direct connection.

tags.name: [params.forceTurn]
tags.description:
- If true, media is not allowed to flow peer-to-peer and must flow through
relay servers. If it cannot flow through relay servers, the call will fail.

tags.name: [params.disableTurn]
tags.description:
- If true, media is not allowed to flow through relay servers; it is
required to flow peer-to-peer. If it cannot, the call will fail.

tags.name: [params.previewLocalMedia]
tags.description:
- A function to call if the developer
wants to perform an action between local media becoming available and calling approve().

tags.name: [params.connectionId]
tags.description:
- The connection ID of the remoteEndpoint, if it is not desired to call
all connections belonging to this endpoint.

tags.name: [params.videoLocalElement]
tags.description:
- Pass in an optional html video element to have local
video attached to it.

tags.name: [params.videoRemoteElement]
tags.description:
- Pass in an optional html video element to have remote
video attached to it.

tags.name: params.id
tags.description: - The name of the group.

tags.name: [params.onSuccess]
tags.description:
- Success handler for this invocation of
this method only.

tags.name: [params.onError]
tags.description:
- Error handler for this invocation of this
method only.

tags.name: [params.onMessage]
tags.description: - Message handler for messages from this group only.

tags.name: [params.onJoin]
tags.description: - Join event listener for endpoints who join this group only.

tags.name: [params.onLeave]
tags.description:
- Leave event listener for endpoints who leave
this group only.

tags.string: {Promise<respoke.Group>|undefined} The instance of the respoke.Group which the client joined.

description.full:
Join a group and begin keeping track of it.

You can leave the group by calling group.leave();

Joining and leaving a group
 var group;

 client.join({
     id: "book-club",
     onSuccess: function (evt) {
         console.log('I joined', evt.group.id);
         // "I joined book-club"
         group = evt.group;
         group.sendMessage({
             message: 'sup'
         });
     }
 });

 // . . .
 // Some time later, leave the group.
 // . . .
 group.leave({
     onSuccess: function (evt) {
         console.log('I left', evt.group.id);
         // "I left book-club"
     }
 });
description.summary: Join a group and begin keeping track of it.
description.body:
You can leave the group by calling group.leave();

Joining and leaving a group
 var group;

 client.join({
     id: "book-club",
     onSuccess: function (evt) {
         console.log('I joined', evt.group.id);
         // "I joined book-club"
         group = evt.group;
         group.sendMessage({
             message: 'sup'
         });
     }
 });

 // . . .
 // Some time later, leave the group.
 // . . .
 group.leave({
     onSuccess: function (evt) {
         console.log('I left', evt.group.id);
         // "I left book-club"
     }
 });

tags.name: name
tags.description: - the event name.

description.full: This event is fired every time the client joins a group. If the client leaves a group, this event will be fired again on the next time the client joins the group.
description.summary: This event is fired every time the client joins a group. If the client leaves a group, this event will be fired again on the next time the client joins the group.

description.full: Add a Group. This is called when we join a group and need to begin keeping track of it.
description.summary: Add a Group. This is called when we join a group and need to begin keeping track of it.

tags.string: {Array<respoke.Group>} All of the groups the library is aware of.

description.full: Get a list of all the groups the client is currently a member of.
description.summary: Get a list of all the groups the client is currently a member of.

tags.name: [params.onJoin]
tags.description: - Receive notification that an endpoint has joined this group.

tags.name: [params.onLeave]
tags.description: - Receive notification that an endpoint has left this group.

tags.name: [params.onMessage]
tags.description:
- Receive notification that a message has been
received to a group.

tags.string: {respoke.Group|undefined} The group whose ID was specified.

description.full:
Find a group by id and return it.

var group = client.getGroup({
    id: "resistance"
});
description.summary: Find a group by id and return it.

tags.string:
TODO Need to account for Endpoints not created as part of a group. These do not need to be
deleted based on group membership.

tags.name: params.id
tags.description: - The ID of the Endpoint to check for removal.

description.full: Remove an Endpoint. Since an endpoint can be a member of multiple groups, we can't just remove it from our list on respoke.Endpoint#leave. We must see if it's a member of any more groups. If it's not a member of any other groups, we can stop keeping track of it.
description.summary: Remove an Endpoint. Since an endpoint can be a member of multiple groups, we can't just remove it from our list on respoke.Endpoint#leave. We must see if it's a member of any more groups. If it's not a member of any other groups, we can stop keeping track of it.

tags.string:
If the endpoint is not found in the local cache of endpoint objects (see `client.getEndpoints()`),
it will be created. This is useful, for example, in the case of dynamic endpoints where groups are
not in use. Override dynamic endpoint creation by setting `params.skipCreate = true`.

tags.name: [params.onMessage]
tags.description:
- Handle messages sent to the logged-in user
from this one Endpoint.

tags.name: [params.onPresence]
tags.description:
- Handle presence notifications from this one
Endpoint.

tags.string: {boolean} [params.skipCreate] - Skip the creation step and return undefined if we don't yet
{respoke.Endpoint} The endpoint whose ID was specified.

description.full:
Find an endpoint by id and return the respoke.Endpoint object.

If it is not already cached locally, will be added to the local cache of tracked endpoints, its presence will be determined, and will be available in client.getEndpoints().

var endpoint = client.getEndpoint({
    id: "dlee"
});
description.summary: Find an endpoint by id and return the respoke.Endpoint object.
description.body:
If it is not already cached locally, will be added to the local cache of tracked endpoints, its presence will be determined, and will be available in client.getEndpoints().

var endpoint = client.getEndpoint({
    id: "dlee"
});

tags.string:
In most cases, if we don't find it we will create it. This is useful
in the case of dynamic endpoints where groups are not in use. Set skipCreate=true
to return undefined if the Connection is not already known.

tags.name: [params.endpointId]
tags.description: - An endpointId to use in the creation of this connection.

tags.name: [params.onMessage]
tags.description:
- Handle messages sent to the logged-in user
from this one Connection.

tags.name: [params.onPresence]
tags.description:
- Handle presence notifications from this one
Connection.

tags.string: {respoke.Connection} The connection whose ID was specified.

description.full:
Find a Connection by id and return it.

var connection = client.getConnection({
    id: "XXXXXXXX-XXXX-XXXX-XXXX-XXXXXXXXXXXXX"
});
description.summary: Find a Connection by id and return it.

description.full:
Get the list of all endpoints that the library has knowledge of. These are respoke.Endpoint objects, not just the endpointIds.

The library gains knowledge of an endpoint in two ways:

  1. when an endpoint joins a group that the user (currently logged-in endpoint) is a member of (if group presence is enabled)
  2. when an endpoint that the user (currently logged-in endpoint) is watching*

*If an endpoint that the library does not know about sends a message to the client, you can immediately call the client.getEndpoint() method on the sender of the message to enable watching of the sender's endpoint.

 client.on('message', function (data) {
     if (data.endpoint) {
         // start tracking this endpoint.
         client.getEndpoint({ id: data.endpoint.id });
     }
 });
description.summary: Get the list of all endpoints that the library has knowledge of. These are respoke.Endpoint objects, not just the endpointIds.
description.body:
The library gains knowledge of an endpoint in two ways:

  1. when an endpoint joins a group that the user (currently logged-in endpoint) is a member of (if group presence is enabled)
  2. when an endpoint that the user (currently logged-in endpoint) is watching*

*If an endpoint that the library does not know about sends a message to the client, you can immediately call the client.getEndpoint() method on the sender of the message to enable watching of the sender's endpoint.

 client.on('message', function (data) {
     if (data.endpoint) {
         // start tracking this endpoint.
         client.getEndpoint({ id: data.endpoint.id });
     }
 });

tags.name: [evt.group]
tags.description:
- If the message is to a group we already know about,
this will be set. If null, the developer can use client.join({id: evt.message.header.channel}) to join
the group. From that point forward, Group#message will fire when a message is received as well. If
group is undefined instead of null, the message is not a group message at all.
